content.description:
A classic testpiece that still inspires and turns back admirer. Get your dry game ready and check your edges. Un challenge qui perdure. Benoît Marion était bien en avance sur son temps et cette voie nous rappelle bien de quoi il était capable. Left of Diableret, you can start from the base or from the ledge higher up (anchor the belayer).

A gauche de Diableret, possible de démarrer d'en bas ou de la vire (faire un relais pour l'assureur.) Some bolts.

Quelques bolts.

Small series of walls with many rests. Petite série de muret avec plusieurs repos. Screws.

Vis à glace.

Pumpy column.  There's a few variations for the first step followed by the steep vertical pillar. 
 Once at the little notch you can stretch it out passed a couple interesting ledges to the trees.

The rightmost column of two clomuns that can easily be seen from pretty far.
Screws

Small delicate pillar left of the initiation wall higher up.

Rappel off trees or walk off right
Screws.

On the frozen wall, starting from a high ledge left of Diablerets.

Very thin ice, poor protection.


Rappel off a tree or walk off right.
Mixed rack, stubbies.

These routes are similar to Diablerets but smaller. The left route when it does not touch the ground offers a mixed route protected by 3 bolts (M7+, FA: Benoit Marion, 1999). Ces cascade sont semblable aux Diablerets mais en plus petit. La voie de gauche lorsqu'elle ne touche pas a terre offre une voie de mixte protégé par 3 bolt (M7+, FA: Benoit Marion, 1999). Continue on the trail to the lake after passing the diableret trail, the ice is clearly visible from the trail.

Continuez sur le chemin vers le lac après avoir passé le sentier pour les diableret, la glace est bien visible du sentier. Ice screws, descent on the left through the trees or rappelling.

Vis à glace, descente à gauche dans les arbres ou en rappel.

Usually comes in as two seperate lines. 30m Rightmost ice, easy to set up top-ropes.

Just keep your ears open for climbers yelling "glace" (ice) every 10 seconds. screws

This is the tiny pillar right of Devil's Tooth and Le Trottoir. It has (4) four bolts that have to be excavated if ice gets low. Very esthetic with rad climbing.

Right most line with (4) bolts
4 bolts + ice screws

The small icefall separates in two, the left one is a bit longer and harder. La petite cascade se sépare en deux, celle de gauche est un peux plus longue et difficile. Gully just left of Diablerets.
Rappel or walk-off left through the trees.

Gully à gauche des Diablerets.
Rappel ou marchez vers la gauche à travers les arbres. Standard rack.

Vis à glace.

A free hanging icicle which forms on top of a rock wall a hundred meters left of Diablerets. It rarely extends low enough to climb after a couple days of rain followed by a quick freeze. Un glaçon suspendu qui se forme au sommet d'une paroi rocheuse à une centaine de mètres à gauche des Diablerets. Il se forme rarement assez bas pour etre grimpé après quelques jours de pluie suivis d'un gel rapide. Standard ice rack.

Vis à glace.

A rarely formed (usually thin) smear of ice that follows a right-leaning depression/crack just right of Devil's tooth.  
  
 Most of the time this route is bare rock. In fat conditions, the Devil's tooth formation can expand rightwards and merge or cover this smear. 
  
 FA unknown - please add this info if you have it. 
 Does not appear in Lapierre/Gagnon guidebook.

Rappel from tree at top of smear. This tree be accessed from top of Devil's tooth to set up a toprope (two 50m ropes required!).
When it's in, a few stubbies. No pins or bolts visible.

In the main flow area, it's the flow to the left of Devil's Tooth. In the main flow area, to the left of the "beginner wall", on the climber's right side of the cliffs. It's the flow to the left of Devil's Tooth (WI5). 45m.
Rappel from the trees, or walk off climbers left or right. Follow the trail. Screws

First section goes up overhanging rock, followed by a detached pillar and a dihedral with some ice on the edges. Route in the hole between Devil's Tooth and Diablerets. Mixed rack.
some bolts and possibly fixed pitons (weak).

To be completed To be completed

To be completed

Classic climb in the Laurentians. Originally done with one wooden shafted ice axe, and ten point crampons. Left Facing big corner. 60m single pitch climb. Two variations, one fairly straight up with a slabby start to short vertical sections with good ice usually. The other is easyish mixed (M2-M3?) with some pins for pro and maybe maybe on a good year some stubbies. Une classique dans les Laurentides, grimpe avec des dix pointes avec un piolet manche en bois. Goulotte qui suit un mur a droite, se fait facilement en une longueur avec une 60m. Deux départs possible, celui de gauche sur la dalle (des fois mince) ou par la droite en mixte (M2-M3?) From Diableret / Devil's Tooth area, go climbers left along the trail and follow the lake (or walk on the lake if it's safe). Once at the bridge, keep heading left along climbers trail until you hit a boulder field, coming from the right, the gully is hidden by a buttress but it's up there! Nice hike up, be warry that some boulders are loose.

A partir du secteur Diableret / Devil's Tooth, descendez vers le lac et suivez le sentier (ou le lac s'il est bien gele) jusqu'au pont. A partir du pont, suivez des sentiers traces par des grimpeurs suivez la paroi en montant un peu jusqu'au pierrier, montez le pierrier pour trouver la goulotte (elle est cache par un éperon lorsqu'on arrive de la droite.)

Double rap or climb to the upper trees and walk off right.

Rappel double (Albalacov possible) on finissez la voie jusqu'en haut et marchez vers la droite. Short screws for the start and single rack if very thin/early season.

Vis courtes pour le départ et rack simple si très mince.

Little icefall.

Just left of Diableries.
Standard rack

A few routes, both easy and what look to be really hard. Bring two 60m ropes if you want to top rope certain long climbs. Also bring slings and screws to set up anchors, there are few bolts. 
  
 This area is very popular on the weekends, so get ready to wait in line, you might find something worthy to climb at St-Hippolyte down the road, if it's in condition. 
  
 Parc des Falaises
